subject: Economics
title: Land Reform and Agricultural Productivity
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Land Reform and Agricultural Productivity.

hook.text: In many developing countries, 5% of landowners own 70% of farmland.

buildup.text: Large estates often sit underused while smallholders farm intensively on scraps.

discovery.text: Japan, Taiwan, and South Korea all did radical land reform after WWII.

twist.text: Latin America's inequality is partly rooted in colonial land grants that were never reformed.

climax.text: Land reform is politically explosive because it takes from the powerful.

punchline.text: The most productive farm is often the smallest one.

quiz.question: What is the 'inverse farm size-productivity relationship'?
options: Larger farms are always more productive
Smaller farms tend to produce more output per acre than large estates, which often sit underused
Farm size has no effect on productivity
